qas.question: Along with British English, what is the major variant of the English language?
What are the two major variants of Serbo-Croatian?
Are British and American English regarded as distinct languages, or dialects of a single language?
Do regional linguists treat Serbian and Croation as distinct languages or as dialects of a single language?
Why are Serbian and Croatian often treated like distinct languages?

answers.text: the two countries oscillate from being brotherly to being bitter enemies

plausible_answers.text: classification of speech varieties as dialects or languages

qas.question: What is can be controversial with consistent verdicts?
Which languages are not spoken by political allies?
Which languages are not spoken by military allies?
Serbian and American English are the major variants of which language?
British English and Croatian American are the major variants of which language?

context: The <b5_0>classification of speech varieties as dialects or languages<b5_0/> and their relationship to other varieties of speech can be controversial and the verdicts inconsistent. <b8_0>English<b8_0/> and <b9_0>Serbo-Croatian<b9_0/> illustrate the point. English and Serbo-Croatian each have two major variants (British and <a0_0>American English<a0_0/>, and <a1_0>Serbian and Croatian<a1_0/>, respectively), along with numerous other varieties. For political reasons, analyzing these varieties as "languages" or "dialects" yields inconsistent results: <b6_0><b7_0>British and American English<b7_0/><b6_0/>, spoken by close political and military allies, are almost universally regarded as <a2_0>dialects of a single language<a2_0/>, whereas the standard languages of Serbia and Croatia, which differ from each other to a similar extent as the dialects of English, are being treated by some linguists from the region as <a3_0>distinct languages<a3_0/>, largely because <a4_0>the two countries oscillate from being brotherly to being bitter enemies<a4_0/>. (The Serbo-Croatian language article deals with this topic much more fully.)
